article.headline: Boone helps UConn rally from halftime deficit
article.linkText: Not half bad: UConn rallies past Sacred Heart
article.story: HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -- Josh Boone knew his coach was mad at halftime, so he went out and did something to change Jim Calhoun's spirits. The UConn center scored 16 second-half points and finished with 20 points and 10 rebounds as the 11th-ranked Huskies (7-1) beat Sacred Heart 73-55 Tuesday night after trailing by three at halftime. "Yeah, coach was upset and rightfully so," Boone said. "That may have been the worst half we've played all year." It was Boone's sixth double-double in eight games this year and the third consecutive game that he has scored his career high. Sacred Heart (1-8) lost its seventh game in a row. Luke Granato led the Pioneers with 19 points. Boone had plenty of help from teammate Charlie Villanueva, as the two UConn big men dominated inside against the smaller Pioneers. Villanueva finished with 17 points, while Rudy Gay and Rashad Anderson each had 11. Sacred Heart was held to just 19 points in the second half by the stifling UConn defense. "I think we held them in the first 12 or 13 minutes of the second half to just six points," Calhoun said. "That took care of that end. Then we went to our two big kids and they scored 15 out of 19. We just told the guys, 'Get the ball inside,' and we finally did a good job with that." Down 36-33 at halftime, UConn wasted no time taking charge, putting together a 12-1 run to open the second half. Granato, who scored 14 first-half points, including four 3-pointers, couldn't get away from the Huskies' defense in the second half as the Pioneers missed four shots and had four turnovers on their first eight possessions. Sacred Heart rallied to pull within 52-47 with 8:27 remaining, but the Huskies responded with a 14-0 run to put the game away. Boone started the run with a rebound basket and two free throws and Villanueva finished it with two driving layups. Sacred Heart, which slowed the game down in the first half, had no answer for UConn's size advantage underneath. "They are superior talents, superior strengths, maybe superior quickness and stuff," Sacred Heart coach Dave Bike said. "They were going to get us down at different times. We ran out of a little gas, that's part of the difference. But we had a chance to win for a long time in this game." Sacred Heart, coming off a 61-point loss at No. 13 Washington, put a scare into the Huskies in the first half. UConn broke out to a 12-4 lead and seemed poised to turn the game into a romp, as it had the previous three times the teams have met. But the Pioneers kept the Huskies within reach and rode Granato's hot hand to score 10 straight points for a shocking 26-24 lead. They played the Huskies evenly for the rest of the half to grab the 3-point edge at halftime. The Huskies, who had allowed Sacred Heart to shoot a sizzling 55.6 percent in the first half, were a different team after the break. "We just turned it around with defense," Villanueva said. "We buckled down and did what we had to do to win the game."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
